<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of named_thread_starter:
```c
static MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_ MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_
named_thread_starter (void *data)
{
  struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *const param =
    (struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *) data;
  void *arg;
  MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ thr_func;

  if (NULL == data)
    return (MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) 0;

  MHD_set_cur_thread_name_ (param->name);

  arg = param->arg;
  thr_func = param->start_routine;
  free (data);

  return thr_func (arg);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function named_thread_starter:
#define MHD_set_cur_thread_name_(n) MHD_set_thread_name_(pthread_self(),(n))
...
struct MHD_named_helper_param_
{
  /**
   * Real thread start routine
   */
  MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ start_routine;

  /**
   * Argument for thread start routine
   */
  void *arg;

  /**
   * Name for thread
   */
  const char *name;
}
...
typedef MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_
(MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_ *MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_)(void *cls)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return thr_func (arg);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: If param->start_routine holds the address of named_thread_starter (i.e. the wrapper was erroneously passed as the ‘real’ start routine), the statement return thr_func(arg); will invoke named_thread_starter indirectly (recursive call). This indirect self-call would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2.
